sentences: In 1986, their debut album was issued by Roadrunner Records.
It took the newcomers only a couple of years to surpass their debut with their sophomore effort, 1988's Transcendence, a joint release on MCA/Roadrunner.
In 1991 they signed to Atlantic Records and released Strange & Beautiful, an album which showed a commercial switch in the band's sound.
Once again, Midnight vanished until late 2004 it was announced that he had joined forces with Black Lotus Records to release his full-length debut solo album, Sakada.
Midnight joined forces with Jon Oliva in 2008 to re-record "Painted Skies" from Transcendence.
In memory of their fallen bandmate, the rest of Crimson Glory played a tribute show, headlining 2009's ProgPower.
Crimson Glory (1986)
Transcendence (1988)
Strange and Beautiful (1991)
The Lost Tape (1998) unreleased
Songs from the Attic (2000)
Sakada (2005)
All Souls Midnight (2008), 100 copies on CD-R
Covers (2009) unreleased
A Strange Tea Party DVD (2009) unreleased
M2: Descending into Madness (2014)
Genius: A Rock Opera (2002): Maindream character
Ben Jackson Group - All Over You (2005): guest vocals on "Rock n' Roll Heaven (Or Bust)"

In 2007, Midnight joined forces with a new group of musicians including Matt LaPorte who also played with the ex-Savatage frontman's band Jon Oliva's Pain, and Lee Harrison the drummer and founder of the death metal band Monstrosity who also previously toured with Obituary and is currently with Terrorizer as well.
Midnight (born John Patrick Jr. McDonald, April 29, 1962 – July 8, 2009) was an American musician best known for being the vocalist of Crimson Glory.
The band became known for Midnight's "ear-shattering screams", which drew comparisons to Geoff Tate, and "painfully strident delivery."
Midnight joined Crimson Glory in the early 1980s.
It took the newcomers only a couple of years to surpass their debut with their sophomore effort, 1988's Transcendence, a joint release on MCA/Roadrunner.
Not long after the latest release, Midnight left the band and the other members dispersed and became involved with various other acts.
For roughly seven years, Midnight remained out of sight.
In the late 1990s, Midnight spent months recording a six-song full-band recording to try to secure a new record deal and some press.

To recover from this huge setback, Midnight reappeared with a low-budget EP originally titled Songs from the Attic which was later re-released simply as M, produced by Tim Fredenburg and featuring Bobby Kovacs on guitar, it explored a more acoustic direction (only 500 copies were made).
Once again, Midnight vanished until late 2004 it was announced that he had joined forces with Black Lotus Records to release his full-length debut solo album, Sakada.
After the release of Sakada, Midnight did a short press tour in Europe which also included several acoustic performances.

Together they recorded, in addition to the All Souls Midnight disc, material for a 20-song covers disc simply titled Covers, a 36 song 3-CD set of original songs titled M2 – Descending into Madness, and a 24-clip DVD documenting the final recordings called A Strange Tea Party, all of which remains unreleased.
Midnight joined forces with Jon Oliva in 2008 to re-record "Painted Skies" from Transcendence.
